meanings.definition: Bitterness or resentfulness, especially when long-standing.
meanings.sent1: The siblings' rancor towards each other lasted for years.
meanings.sent2: The rancor in her voice was evident as she spoke about the betrayal.
meanings.sent3: Despite their rancor, they managed to work together on the project.
meanings.sent4: The rancor between the two rival teams was palpable on the field.
meanings.sent5: The old man's eyes held a deep rancor towards the world.

meanings.definition: To feel or express bitterness or resentfulness.
meanings.sent1: She rancored silently, unable to let go of the past hurt.
meanings.sent2: He rancors about the unfair treatment he received at work.
meanings.sent3: The cat seemed to rancor at the sight of the new puppy in the house.
meanings.sent4: As the argument escalated, he began to rancor his frustrations out loud.
meanings.sent5: She rancored her disappointment in a letter to the company.
